text: in the perfect kickoff to another long
work week two of the emblems of
corporate drudgery have decided to join
forces what is the deal LinkedIn best
known for those annoying contact
requests from people you barely met a
year ago in a meeting is being bought by
Microsoft the famed creator of excel
word Outlook and PowerPoint and
everything you hate about turning on
your computer the deal value is $26
billion
LinkedIn went public in 2011 and its
shares had soared as high as
$269 but concerns about rapidly slowing
growth and a lack of profits led to it
shares falling as low as $100 per share
the Microsoft deal at $196 is a nice
recovery compared to those
depths the company wants to be at the
Forefront of so-called productivity and
collaboration all those software things
you do at work it believes it can
integrate LinkedIn into its software
offerings so office workers can be more
efficient or useful still Microsoft
doesn't have a strong record in
Acquisitions and Tech m&a is notoriously
tricky Microsoft's vast War chest For
Better or Worse does allow it to make
big bets the company has a market
capitalization of $400 billion and a
cash balance of hundred billion because
interest rates remain low it can buy
LinkedIn for a big premium without its
earnings being diluted very much
while Facebook continues to thrive the
rest of the industry is struggling quite
a bit Twitter shares however did rally
5% on Monday because there is hope that
there's another big dumb tech company
willing to spend tens of billions of
dollars to rescue it we shall see this
is suji nup Financial Times New York
news that Warren Buffett's company
birkshire hathway has invested over a
billion dollars in Apple has prompted
question
about both buyer and Target
